element.name: St Bridgets Well by Windsockers, Multi-cache (1/1.5)
element.long-description:
St Bridget
Daughter of Dubtach, pagan Scottish king of Leinster, and Brocca, a Christian Pictish slave who had been baptized by Saint Patrick. Just before Brigid's birth, her mother was sold to a Druid landowner. Brigid remained with her mother till she was old enough to serve her legal owner Dubtach, her father.
Holy Wells
The existence of holy wells in Ireland today offer an opportunity to witness sacred sites and rituals that have continued since prehistoric times. Where once a sacrifice may have taken place, today a bride might look into the waters for inspiration or good luck; a cripple might bathe in the waters in search of a cure. Often the stations of the cross are prayed or a special Mass is said. A ritual practice dating from prehistoric times and continuing today is that of circumambulation, or making structured rounds of the well, always in a clockwise direction.
The Celts, a grain-cultivating, cattle-raising people, had a strong religious influence on the native Irish. One of the features of Irish Celtic cosmogony is the power of place. This, to an earth-centered religion (i.e. goddess as opposed to the god in the sky), means that certain places possess power that is curative and regenerative. This power of place in Ireland is an essential element of the sacredness of the holy well.
There are different types of wells, briefly one might say that prior to the coming of St. Patrick, and the sacred springs reflected the Celtic earth-centered spirituality. After Patrick, there occurred a shift to "Christianize" the pilgrimages and practices associated with the wells. So the loric phenomena associated with many of the wells was revalorized in terms and by symbols universally understood in Christianity a crossing of the boundary between the two cultures. The pagan tree took on the symbolism of Christ (i.e. the cross) and there sprang up throughout the country St. Patrick wells and also St. Bridget wells.
This spring is located behind the local Roman Catholic Church in the village of St. Margaret’s in north Co. Dublin. Spring water is contained in a large rectangular well chamber approximately 6 m long by 3 m wide. An overflow pipe leads to a ditch which carries water at times of high spring discharge. The substratum appears to be semi-natural and consists of rocks, cobbles, pebbles, and some mud. Evidence indicates that this spring completely dries out each year, usually during the summer period although anecdotal evidence also indicates that the spring well retained water throughout the year before approximately 1980.
The Curse
Desecrate this holy place
And join the devils legions
Drinking water will be scarce
In fiery nether regions
The Cache
Stage One
To find the cache you need to visit the above location and take note of the year Hugh Connor died call this A.B.C.D
Stage Two
Go to N 53 25.854 W 006 18.178 once there take note of date that the man who had the well enclosed died call this E.F.G.H
Final Location
The Cache is at N 53 DF.8F(D+H) W 006 EG.A(A+F)C
The Windsockers

ul.li:
2010-05-25T19:00:00Z : Found it by Serapis
I was stumped here before and my maths obviously was wrong (but not that wrong as to put it somewhere mad). Today I found the cache quickly in the end. The well was still dry. Interesting to see the inscription of the St Brigids cross ‘tilted’ to one side as a sort of an X shape as opposed the more usual + shape. It could be a Masonic plot. Or there again it mightn’t be… Anyway thanks for the cache. Signed log. Serapis.

2010-05-08T19:00:00Z : Found it by Fitzet
This was a 'Windsockers' themed day of cache finds around the airport. This was #6 of 7.
We met the proprietor of the nearby church and he seemed totally bemused but pleased that locals would be walking to look at the well. This is my favourite sort of cache. I love finding ancient places that I never knew existed.
In Nurse finger puppet. Out Stretchy Man
SL TFTC

2010-03-06T20:00:00Z : Found it by niripas
Nice multi! Tried to get the second set of numbers and almost got into water... Be careful with the gate! Ofcourse got the number wrong and ended up in to the field. Returned to the well, got the number right and found the cache without any problems!
TFTC!

2010-02-07T20:00:00Z : Found it by Toffee Man
First find of the day on a trip around the Swords area. Found the well easily enough & worked out the co-ords for the cache. After a while looking we reassesed & then found the cache. TFTC. Toffee Man. #171

2010-02-07T20:00:00Z : Found it by Blue Jay 59
Interesting place and nice history too. I wonder is this the same St.Bridget from my parish? The curse is a bit scary, I preferred the blessing on the other side [:)] How do you find these places?? Arrived in time for all the mass going muggles to pour out, but they didn't bother us and we didn't bother them. Found the clues and then found the cache. TFTC Blue Jay 59 #172

wpt.name: GC13KM1
wpt.desc: St Bridgets Well by Windsockers, Multi-cache (1/1.5)

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: St Bridgets Well
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
St Bridget

Daughter of Dubtach, pagan Scottish king of Leinster, and Brocca, a Christian Pictish slave who had been baptized by Saint Patrick. Just before Brigid's birth, her mother was sold to a Druid landowner. Brigid remained with her mother till she was old enough to serve her legal owner Dubtach, her father.

The existence of holy wells in Ireland today offer an opportunity to witness sacred sites and rituals that have continued since prehistoric times. Often the stations of the cross are prayed or a special Mass is said. A ritual practice dating from prehistoric times and continuing today is that of circumambulation, or making structured rounds of the well, always in a clockwise direction.


The Celts, a grain-cultivating, cattle-raising people, had a strong religious influence on the native Irish. One of the features of Irish Celtic cosmogony is the power of place. This, to an earth-centered religion (i.e. goddess as opposed to the god in the sky), means that certain places possess power that is curative and regenerative. In fiery nether regions

The Cache

Stage One

To find the cache you need to visit the above location and take note of the year Hugh Connor died call this A.B.C.D

Stage Two

Go to N 53 25.854 W 006 18.178 once there take note of date that the man who had the well enclosed died call this E.F.G.H

Final Location

The Cache is at N 53 DF.8F(D+H) W 006 EG.A(A+F)C


The Windsockers

Additional Waypoints

FN13KM1 - Final
N/S __ ° __ . ___ W/E ___ ° __ . ___

S213KM1 - Stage 2
N 53° 25.854 W 006° 18.178
